section.name: TLS/SSL Support
section.p: This document explains how to enable Apache FTP Server to use Transport Layer Security (TLS) for encrypted client-server communication.

James uses the Sun Java Secure Sockets Extension (JSSE) infrastructure to provide TLS/SSL sockets. JSSE comes packaged with several vendor Java distributions (i.e. Sun Java 1.4.x, IBM Java 1.3.x). For these distributions, please follow the vendor provided instructions for configuring the JVM to use JSSE services.

section.name: Implicit Security
section.p: If you want to use implicit SSL connection. The first thing you need to do is to set appropriate server socket factory. (org.apache.ftpserver.socketfactory.SSLFtpSocketFactory). If you use SSLFtpSocketFactory, you must specify the "ssl" configuration parameters.

tr.td: Keystore file location. One sample keystore file (res/.keystore) has been provided with the distribution.
Keystore password. The sample keystore password : password
The keystore type. The sample keystore type : JKS
Keystore algorithm. The sample keystore algorithm : SunX509
SSL protocol. The default SSL protocol is TLS
Client authentication is required. The default is false.
Key password. The sample keystore key password : password

section.p: Implicit secure socket does not ensure encrypted data transfer. To use SSL/TLS in data connection, client has to send "PROT P" command. You also need to set the keystore configuration parameters. Encrypted data transfer is supported for FTP passive (PASV) mode only.

section.name: Explicit Security
section.p: In this mode server supports both secure and non-secure connection. Upon request from client (AUTH SSL) the server switches to the SSL/TLS mode.
In this case, the default server socket factory (org.apache.ftpserver.socketfactory.FtpSocketFactory) has to be used.

section.p: If you want to use secure data transfer, you have to set config.data-connection.ssl parameters like implicit security.
